job_title: Health and Fitness Coordinator in Des Moines, WA
pros: The residents are fun, compassionate, and a joy to be around! The residents are supportive of everyone on staff and living on campus. Best part for me was how committed to their fitness journey they are, we would have a class of almost 30 people regularly come to aerobic and sit down fitness classes!
cons: The pay and health benefits could be more competitive. Teams were consistently short staffed which affected quality of work.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Auburn, WA
pros:
*nice place for residents
*ok benefits
cons:
*low pay
*bad management
* heavy workload

pros:
This was probably the best job I could have picked as a first timer. If you're a server, like I was, your teammates are basically all in the same age bracket, so I made a lot of friends while I was here. The shifts were also very flexible, and accommodated my class schedules with ease. If I could only work weekends because I had Monday through Thursday classes, they made it work. If high school students had class from 8am until 2pm, the dinner shifts didn't start until 3:30.

Also, working with the same residents day in and day out, you got to know them all on a first name basis and develop long-term relationships with them. Seeing the servers at breakfast, lunch, and dinner were always the highlights of their day. Heck, even though I don't work there anymore, I've actually gone back to visit some of them to catch up and see how they're doing. You definitely need to be a friendly and sociable person to work here.
cons:
Because it was a non-profit organization, the yearly raises were minimal. After nearly six years of working there, I only made a dollar more than when I started. However, because this was a job meant to get me through high school and college, it was enough at the time. It's perfect for high school and college students who want extra spending money.

And because you are working with the elderly, you don't get tips. However, at the end of the year, everyone gets a "bonus" gift from the residents.

pros: The administration is great to work with!
cons: There are no cons whatsoever

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Moines, WA
pros:
I appreciate the support I've received from upper management. I've had the flexibility to make changes and test new ideas. I decided to work here because of the strong missions statement, and the overall company vision. 

So far I've experienced clear and open communications from staff and upper management. I love how there isn't a strict hierarchical attitude within upper management. People's voices and opinions are heard without repercussion.  

The residents are amazing, and a pleasure to work with. If you have doubts about working for a retirement community because of the stigma associated with them, don't! The residents love it here and it shows. 

The greatest pro of this company is the mission, and being able to work toward a positive goal and see real results on a daily basis.
cons:
Non profits sometimes have a difficult time staying competitive with pay. 

The administrative offices are located in one of the resident buildings, which was built in the 50's. The offices could use updating. On the plus side this building is going to be redeveloped completely in the next 5 years.

pros: I have worked at the Wesley homes Lea Hill campus for 41/2 yrs. It is life enriching work. The residents  become  a part of your family as you  love  and care for them, they give it right back with their appreciation and caring for you(lots of hugs& smiles.) The  staff team is strong .Most of the  team members have been there since it was opened in 2007.  We work together as a team helping and covering work needs in each others department. We are given the  empowerment and trust  to do what is right  for the resident.  Is it perfect? No..but we have a campus director who has great wisdom and  with an open door policy and ease of contact with him, things get solved (sometimes not as fast as I want it to) as he is easy to talk with.
cons: Lea Hill is new and more together than Des Moines Campus. Sometime DM hinders us with there lack of team work and knowledge

pros: Great events for the residents.
cons: Working here you rarely get recognized for the work you do. Management and staff is promoted based on who you know not the work you do. New staff is not welcomed and management and staff members that have been there for awhile feel threatened by the new comers that do well. If black balled you will never grow in the company, Administration needs a new lead that doesn't favor and promote staff that are related to other staff members. This is the worst company to work for if you want to succeed and recognized and treated fair. This is not an equal opportunity employer. If you want peace and happiness in your life this is the  wrong choice. I would rate this place a negative 0 not even 1 star.

review_title: Admins make up to 400k but say this job isn't about money
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Moines, WA
pros: Perfect job to afford a minimalistic lifestyle. Trips to the gym unnecessary. Easy to watch your diet because you have no time to eat.
cons: Greedy administration and management. Minimum wage workers are expected to slowly take on more wor and watch their coworkers drop like flies while administration refuses to replace those who quit. The resulting consequences trickle down to the residents. Workers who are stretched thin unintentionally neglect or endanger themselves, coworkers, and residents trying to meet the demands of their superiors.

review_title: Fulfilling but can be difficult with rude elderly or lazy coworkers.
job_title: Diet Aide in Des Moines, WA
pros: Helping the elderly can be rewarding, some are kind and fun to interact with. Christmas bonuses and a retirement plan that's matched 4% are nice, too.
cons: The elderly can be rude and overly demanding. Your job is very physical and has to be completed in short periods of time. You have to be the bad guy and enforce rules for safety and as a result the residents or other departments become frustrated.

pros: Great patients, next to the marina.
cons: Very High turnover, low wages and very expensive benefits, very poor culture, hostile environment (a lot of finger pointing and favoritism especially by the ED) , everyone gets the same merit increases even poor performers, executive leadership is non-existent, brash and hardly interacts with staff, very low morale and very little focus spent on team building and employee appreciation.

pros: If you're the sort of person who wants to feel like you're contributing to the community again by working for a non-profit, Wesley Homes will definitely welcome you.
cons: They will also overwork and stifle you, so better be late in your career, don't really care about the pay, or benefits, or...anything else.

review_title: Wesley Homes, Des Moines Campus-- a great place to work, serve and grow
pros: Collaborative environment, growth opportunities, engaged employees, care of residents, outstanding mission, beautiful grounds.   This is a phenomenal place to work if you truly want to make an impact.
cons: Paid time off (such as an increase in paid holidays for example) could be looked at.   Employees may appreciate having more than 6 paid holidays per year.    Some of the technology tools could be updated to provide additional efficiencies.

pros: Great location away from lots of traffic.
cons: Found out that not only does Wesley only offer 6 paid holidays per year, but they also don't give merit raises.  Everyone gets the same increase per year.  Good, bad, excellent all get the same COLA (cost of living adjustment) raise each year.  Very Demoralizing.  Very un-motivating.  Why try harder when the slackers get the same raise?
